title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the muscular system made up of?

options.label: C
options.text: Three main muscle types: skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the muscular system?

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate the movement of blood

options.label: C
options.text: To produce almost all the movements we make

multiple-choice.question: What type of muscle contraction creates a stabilizing force?

options.label: C
options.text: No change in muscle fiber length

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the autonomic nervous system in relation to the muscular system?

options.label: A
options.text: To control the movement of skeletal muscles

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the heart rate and blood pressure

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the body's weight is made up of skeletal muscles?
What type of muscle fibers are endurance cells and react slowly to use energy?

options.label: A
options.text: To attach the cheek to the teeth

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the movement of the jaw

What percentage of the body's warmth is provided by muscle?
What is the main byproduct of muscle contraction?

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of the cyclops sheep deformity?

options.label: A
options.text: Poisonous plants with an active molecule

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic mutation in the hedgehog gene

options.label: C
options.text: A virus that infected the pregnant ewes

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the gene that, when mutated, produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog?
What is the function of the hedgehog protein in normal healthy development?

options.label: B
options.text: To release a protein that blocks smoothened

options.label: C
options.text: To tell cells where to go and what kind of tissues to become

multiple-choice.question: What happens when cyclopamine binds to smoothened?

options.label: A
options.text: It activates smoothened, allowing it to send signals

options.label: B
options.text: It inhibits smoothened, preventing it from sending signals

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on smoothened

options.label: D
options.text: It blocks smoothened from passing along its chemical message

multiple-choice.question: What is the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein?
What were the two drugs that were approved in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines?

options.label: C
options.text: Two closely related molecules of cyclopamine

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the researchers' decision to investigate the cyclops sheep deformity?

options.label: A
options.text: They found a new type of genetic mutation

options.label: C
options.text: They turned a mystery into medicine

options.label: D
options.text: They were unable to find a cause

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the scientist who led the team that discovered the connection between the hedgehog gene and the cyclops sheep deformity?
What was the effect of feeding lab rats with samples of local flora on the researchers' hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It supported their hypothesis that the sheep ate poisonous plants

options.label: B
options.text: It failed to replicate the effect

options.label: C
options.text: It had no effect on their hypothesis

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a new hypothesis

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of performing genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice?

options.label: B
options.text: They developed severe defects in their brains, organs, and eyes

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why authorities banned the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals in the 13thirteenth century?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were difficult to use

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were considered easier to forge or alter

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were less familiar to customers than to merchants

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were considered too complex

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Pythagorean mathematician that discovered irrational numbers, which were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe?
What was the punishment that Hippasus was said to have received for publicizing his discovery of irrational numbers?
In what century did Florence ban the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping?
What was the main reason why negative numbers were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were difficult to calculate

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were considered to have no practical application

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were seen as a threat to the concept of zero

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were not well understood

multiple-choice.question: Who was the mathematician that avoided using zero, even though it would have made it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations?
What is the reason why some numbers are considered illegal today?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are difficult to use

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are considered to have symbolic meaning

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not well understood

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the idea of illegal numbers gather attention when code that could be used to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed in the form of a large prime number?
Who was the mathematician that said "the mathematician's pencil grows stronger by the day"?
What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The history of numbers and their development

options.label: B
options.text: The importance of mathematics in everyday life

options.label: C
options.text: The power of words and numbers to shape society

options.label: D
options.text: The history of mathematics and its impact on society

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: Our brains are separate from our bodies

options.label: D
options.text: Our bodies are controlled by our brains

options.text: Our senses are separate from our subjective consciousness

options.label: B
options.text: Our senses are deeply integrated with our subjective consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Our senses are controlled by our subjective consciousness

options.label: D
options.text: Our subjective consciousness is separate from our senses

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea of a non-physical consciousness, as discussed in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our consciousness is separate from our physical bodies

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that our consciousness is a product of our physical bodies

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that our consciousness is an illusion

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that our consciousness is a separate entity from our bodies

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:
Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: The former is more reliable, while the latter is more valid.

options.label: B
options.text: The former is more valid, while the latter is more reliable.

options.label: C
options.text: The former measures aptitude, while the latter measures achievement.

options.label: D
options.text: The former measures achievement, while the latter measures aptitude.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Administer the test as is, and use the results to evaluate students' reading comprehension skills.

options.label: B
options.text: Modify the test to make it more reading-heavy, and less math-heavy.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a different test that is more reading-focused, and less math-focused.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the test results, and use other methods to evaluate students' reading comprehension skills.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Standardized tests are too short, and don't allow for enough time to assess these skills.

options.label: B
options.text: Standardized tests are too long, and can be overwhelming for test-takers.

options.label: C
options.text: Standardized tests are not designed to measure these skills, and may not be valid or reliable.

options.label: D
options.text: D: Standardized tests are too easy, and don't challenge test-takers enough.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: A ruler and a tape measure

options.label: B
options.text: A thermometer and a weather vane

options.label: C
options.text: A broken clock and a working clock

options.label: D
options.text: A thermometer and a broken thermometer

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the tests are fun and engaging for test-takers.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the tests are easy and don't challenge test-takers.

options.label: C
options.text: To use the right tests for the right jobs, and to interpret results appropriately.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the results of the tests, and use other methods to evaluate test-takers.

multiple-choice.question: Application Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Administer the test as is, and use the results to evaluate students' language proficiency.

options.label: B
options.text: Modify the test to make it more culturally sensitive, and less biased.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a different test that is more culturally sensitive, and less biased.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the test results, and use other methods to evaluate students' language proficiency.

multiple-choice.question: Analytical Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Test-takers may become bored or disengaged.

options.label: B
options.text: Test-takers may become anxious or stressed.

options.label: C
options.text: Test results may be misinterpreted or misused.

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: Standardized tests are too short, and don't allow for enough time to assess individual students.

options.label: B
options.text: Standardized tests are too long, and can be overwhelming for individual students.

options.label: C
options.text: Standardized tests can't tell us a lot about a single person, and usually can't tell us how smart someone is, or how they will handle a tough situation.

options.label: D
options.text: Standardized tests are too easy, and don't challenge individual students enough.

multiple-choice.question: Conceptual Question:

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the tests are fun and engaging for test-takers.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the tests are easy and don't challenge test-takers.

options.label: C
options.text: To design tests that are valid and reliable, and that measure what they are supposed to measure.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the results of the tests, and use other methods to evaluate test-takers.

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is an executive order in the context of the U.S. government?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of legislation passed by Congress

options.label: B
options.text: A decision made by a federal judge

options.label: C
options.text: A directive issued by the president without Congressional approval

options.label: D
options.text: A law that can only be enforced by the executive branch

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between an executive order and a law?

options.label: A
options.text: An executive order is more permanent than a law

options.label: B
options.text: A law requires Congressional approval, while an executive order does not

options.label: C
options.text: An executive order is only enforceable by the executive branch

options.label: D
options.text: An executive order is only used in times of emergency

options.text: To clarify and implement a policy

options.label: C
options.text: To appoint a new Supreme Court justice

options.label: D
options.text: To declare war on another country

options.label: C
options.text: To build roads, bridges, and parks throughout the country

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Harry Truman's executive order to establish faith-based initiatives

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By a veto from the president's successor

options.label: A
options.text: FDR's executive order to intern Japanese-Americans

options.label: B
options.text: Harry Truman's executive order to desegregate the armed forces

options.label: C
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's executive order to establish faith-based initiatives

options.label: D
options.text: FDR's executive order to establish the WPA

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By issuing an executive order to establish a new federal agency

options.label: C
options.text: By issuing an executive order to expand the power of a federal agency

options.label: D
options.text: By issuing an executive order to declare war on another country

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A veto from the president's successor

title: What are gravitational waves? - Amber L. Stuver

multiple-choice.question: What event was witnessed by scientists on September 14, 2015, that no human had ever seen before?

options.label: A
options.text: The collision of two neutron stars

options.label: B
options.text: The collision of two black holes

options.label: D
options.text: The formation of a new galaxy

multiple-choice.question: What is the force that pulls any two objects together?
What are gravitational waves, according to the theory of general relativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Ripples in space-time caused by the movement of objects

options.label: B
options.text: Waves in a physical medium, such as water or air

options.label: C
options.text: Particles that carry energy and momentum

multiple-choice.question: What would a gravitational wave feel like, if our bodies were sensitive enough to detect it?

options.label: B
options.text: Like being stretched sideways while being compressed vertically

options.label: C
options.text: Like a strong gust of wind

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO)?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of black holes and neutron stars

options.label: C
options.text: To search for dark matter and dark energy

options.label: D
options.text: To study the expansion of the universe

multiple-choice.question: What is the signature sound of a gravitational wave, as detected by LIGO?

options.label: B
options.text: A chirp, similar to a slide whistle

multiple-choice.question: What other high-energy astronomical events can produce gravitational waves, in addition to black hole collisions?

options.label: D
options.text: Solar flares and coronal mass ejections

multiple-choice.question: What has LIGO already revealed about the universe, in the short time it has been operational?

options.label: A
options.text: That black holes are not as massive as previously thought

options.label: B
options.text: That black holes collide more often than expected

options.label: C
options.text: That gravitational waves are not as strong as predicted

options.label: D
options.text: That the universe is expanding at a slower rate than thought

multiple-choice.question: What kind of tool is LIGO, in terms of detecting gravitational waves?

options.label: A
options.text: To reveal new information about the universe, but not to revolutionize our understanding

options.label: B
options.text: To confirm existing theories and models of the universe

options.label: C
options.text: To discover new phenomena and challenges existing theories

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a new way of perceiving the universe

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary misconception about the human brain's left and right sides?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side controls only movement.

options.label: B
options.text: The left side controls only language.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls logic and the right controls creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain has no left and right sides.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the crossing over of visual information in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To improve vision in low light conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: To enable quicker reflexes in response to predators.

options.label: C
options.text: To allow for more efficient processing of visual information.

options.label: D
options.text: To compensate for the difference in eye size.

multiple-choice.question: Which neurologists first suggested that language is controlled by the left side of the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Robert Louis Stevenson and his characters Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde

options.label: C
options.text: Albert Einstein and his theory of relativity

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of examining patients who were missing a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated?

options.label: A
options.text: They showed a limited range of behaviors.

options.label: B
options.text: They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative.

options.label: C
options.text: They showed no change in behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the brain's right side in controlling movement?

options.label: A
options.text: The right side controls the motion of the left arm and leg.

options.label: B
options.text: The right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: C
options.text: The right side controls the motion of both arms and legs.

options.label: D
options.text: The right side has no role in controlling movement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between logic and creativity in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: They are located in separate areas of the brain and are mutually exclusive.

options.label: B
options.text: They are located in separate areas of the brain but can be used together.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not separate areas of the brain and are not mutually exclusive.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not related to each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of the brain's left-right structure in controlling vision and movement?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more efficient processing of visual information.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables quicker reflexes in response to predators.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for more precise control of movement.

multiple-choice.question: Who introduced the idea of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional right hemisphere?
What is the relationship between language and the brain's left side?

options.label: A
options.text: Language is controlled by the right side of the brain that is more active.

options.label: B
options.text: Language is localized to the left side of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Language is controlled by the right side of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Language has no relationship to the left side of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary conclusion of later research on the brain's left-right structure?

options.label: A
options.text: One side of the brain is more active than the other for all functions.

options.label: B
options.text: One side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system rather than by person.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain has no left and right sides.

options.label: D
options.text: The left and right sides of the brain are completely separate and have no overlap.

title: How does caffeine keep us awake? - Hanan Qasim

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate amount of caffeine consumed worldwide every year?

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's

options.label: C
options.text: Having no effect on the risk of diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the potential long-term benefit of caffeine consumption is not related to diseases

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on it

options.label: D
options.text: It has a mixed effect on it

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has no effect on performance

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when caffeine consumption is suddenly stopped?

options.text: It has no effect on the body

title: How to spot a misleading graph - Lea Gaslowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is one common way graphs can misrepresent data?

options.label: C
options.text: By using only a few data points

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the technique used to manipulate the x-axis in line graphs?
What is one way to avoid being misled by a graph?

options.label: A
options.text: By assuming the difference in the size of the bars is proportional to the values

options.label: B
options.text: By looking at the labels, the numbers, the scale, and the context

options.label: D
options.text: By trusting the graph without question

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential problem with leaving out relevant data in a graph?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the graph more accurate

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the graph's accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the graph more difficult to understand

options.label: C
options.text: 5 centimeters in diameter and 0.2 kilograms in weight

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common type of crystal that forms kidney stones?

options.label: B
options.text: The stone becomes smaller and easier to pass

options.label: C
options.text: The stone scratches the walls of the urinary tract and causes pain

options.label: D
options.text: The stone blocks the flow of urine and causes infection

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Placing a stent in the ureter

options.label: C

title: How does asthma work? - Christopher E. Gaw

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary characteristic of the airways in people with asthma?

options.label: A
options.text: They are relaxed and wide open.

options.label: B
options.text: They are chronically inflamed and hyper-responsive to triggers.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only affected during an asthma attack.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in the larger airways.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of smooth muscle constriction in the airways during an asthma attack?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the production of mucus.

options.label: B
options.text: It widens the airways, allowing more air to pass through.

options.label: C
options.text: It results in the feeling of chest tightness.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the inflammation in the airways.

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon known as hyperinflation, which can occur during an asthma attack?

options.label: A
options.text: The trapping of air inside the lungs forces the body to work harder to move air in and out of them.

options.label: B
options.text: The airways become too narrow to allow air to pass through.

options.label: C
options.text: The lungs become too large to fit inside the chest cavity.

options.label: D
options.text: The body becomes too efficient at exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary treatment for asthma?
What type of medication is contained in reliever inhalers?
What is the primary effect of corticosteroids in preventive inhalers?

options.label: A
options.text: They widen the airways, allowing more air to pass through.

options.label: B
options.text: They reduce airway sensitivity and inflammation.

options.label: C
options.text: They increase the production of mucus.

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to contribute to the development of asthma, according to recent research?

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of genetic and environmental factors

multiple-choice.question: What may be a reason why poverty is linked to asthma incidents?

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure to additional pollutants and environmental irritants

options.label: B
options.text: Difficulty in obtaining medical care or treatment

multiple-choice.question: What is the main effect of an asthma attack on the body's ability to deliver oxygen to its organs and tissues?

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on oxygen delivery.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of an untreated severe asthma attack?

options.label: A
options.text: The airways become too narrow to allow air to pass through.

options.label: B
options.text: The body becomes too efficient at exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide.

options.label: C
options.text: The body can't keep up with the demand for oxygen, leading to death from lack of oxygen.

options.label: D
options.text: The inflammation in the airways is reduced.

multiple-choice.question: Where did scientists crack open the nucleus at the center of the uranium atom for the first time and create a chain reaction?

options.label: B
options.text: High construction costs and public opposition

options.label: D
options.text: Limited energy output and high waste production

options.text: The need for a controlled chain reaction

What is the challenge of safely containing radioactive fission products, which can take hundreds of thousands of years to decay?

options.label: B
options.text: The challenge of cooling the reactor

options.label: C
options.text: The difficulty of containing radioactive waste

options.label: D
options.text: The need for a controlled chain reaction
